Unnamed: 3: 201-4 Financial assistance received from government
Unnamed: 4:
No financial assistance is sought or received from government.
Transurban builds and manages infrastructure in many cases with upfront
government co-investment, but this is a business relationship and is reflected
in the contractual terms of the tolling concession granted to Transurban.

Unnamed: 3: 204-1 Proportion of spending on local suppliers
Unnamed: 4:
Transurban operates in urban centres of Australia (Melbourne, Sydney,
Brisbane), the United States (Virginia) and Canada (Montreal). The vast
majority of TransurbanÃ¢ÂÂs supply chain spend is on suppliers and activities that
are physically, locally based around our roads, projects, and offices in each
respective city. Some spending relates to group-wide services or technology
services that are shared across regions.

Unnamed: 3: 205-1 Operations assessed for risks related to corruption
Unnamed: 4: Transurban has an organisational wide enterprise risk management approach spanning all projects, operations. This approach is linked with our contract management framework and supported by a mandatory Ethical Business Practices Training course.\n\nAs a result, fraud, corruption, bribery risks are considered across the full enterprise, operations and our business activities. As a result of these reviews no current significant exposure to these types of risks has been identified.

Unnamed: 3: 205-2 Communication and training about anti-corruption policies and procedures
Unnamed: 4: Training on anti-corruption policies and procedures are undertaken annually\nacross the organisation. It is pushed out to all employees in Australia, North America and Canada. 99% of employees completed the training FY23. Employee opinions about the effectiveness of controls are assessed via the Ã¢ÂÂOur VoiceÃ¢ÂÂ survey. Training is supported by internal communication.

Unnamed: 3: 205-3 Confirmed incidents of corruption and actions taken
Unnamed: 4: Transurban has not been exposed to any corruption related incidents and therefore no action against employees or service providers has been required.

Unnamed: 3: 206-1 Legal actions for anti-competitive behavior, anti-trust, and monopoly practices
Unnamed: 4: None in FY23

Unnamed: 3: 301-1 Materials used by weight or volume
Unnamed: 4: Transurban is developing a Sustainable Resource Strategy that will improve our measurement of materials and waste and set group-wide targets. We currently monitor materials quantities on major projects on an individual basis, and are developing group-wide materials quantities totals.\n\nRefer to FY23 Corporate Report/Business partners and suppliers, for case studies on materials quantities used in construction projects, including materials and embodied emissions reductions achieved.

Unnamed: 3: 301-3 Reclaimed products and their packaging materials
Unnamed: 4: TransurbanÃ¢ÂÂs only physical product is tolling tags which are provided to customers to enable toll road travel. Tags that are returned by customers and still function may be reused. Tags that no longer work are returned to our supplier where they are dismantled into their separate components for appropriate recycling or disposal.\n\nRefer to the Waste tab in this FY23 Sustainability data pack for data on customer tag collection and reuse/recycling.

Unnamed: 3: 302-5 Reductions in energy requirements of products and services
Unnamed: 4: By providing customers with safer, faster and more free-flowing travel choices on our roads, we estimate that on average our customers save on average 28% of their fuel usage driving on a Transurban toll road compared to the next best available un-tolled alternative route.\nRefer to FY23 Corporate Report/Communities for details on customer vehicle\ntime and emissions savings.

Unnamed: 3: 303-1 Interactions with water as a shared resource
Unnamed: 4: TransurbanÃ¢ÂÂs water use and impacts include:\nÃ¢ÂÂ¢ The use of potable or recycled water for our operations including offices, road cleaning and maintenance, fire control systems, and irrigation\nÃ¢ÂÂ¢ Management of stormwater and groundwater flows on our assets, including treatment and discharge

Unnamed: 3: 303-2 Management of water discharge-related impacts
Unnamed: 4:
The majority of Transurban's water discharge relates to stormwater from road drainage and groundwater seepage into tunnels. Water is managed in line with asset specific criteria/guidelines determined by the locality, relevant legislation and receiving environment.
This includes drainage of stormwater to basins, treatment of groundwater in water treatment
plants prior to discharge. On CityLink, treated groundwater is reinjected into the aquifer, a
unique need on this asset.

Unnamed: 3: 304-2 Significant impacts of activities, products and services on biodiversity
Unnamed: 4: Transurban intends to develop a broader company-wide biodiversity strategy. \nCurrently Flora and fauna management plans are maintained at the regional level consistent with local regulations and habitat.\nIn some areas, motorways pass through areas of fragmented natural habitat and have impacts on wildlife movement. This also leads to the potential for animals crossing motorways. Where applicable, Transurban maintains motorway fencing and fauna crossing availability to channel animals to safe crossing locations.

Unnamed: 3: 304-3 Habitats protected or restored
Unnamed: 4: Ongoing habitat restoration projects included partnering with Landcare Australia on the Power St Loop in Melbourne and M2 Motorscapes in Sydney.\nMajor projects also have a focus on protecting or enhancing local habitat where possible. The Logan Enhancement Project in Brisbane included a major Ã¢ÂÂfauna bridgeÃ¢ÂÂ and wildlife\nconnectivity improvements.

Unnamed: 3: 304-4 IUCN Red List species and national conservation list species with habitats in areas affected by operations
Unnamed: 4: TransurbanÃ¢ÂÂs A25 bridge in Montreal spans a river inhabited by sturgeon, which are present on the IUCN Red List with some species listed as endangered.
